The only negative comment I have of the hotel as a whole is that we felt the rooms themselves could do with a makeover â€“ seemed a bit on the tired and dowdy side. I was especially surprised to see an old fashioned CRT TV â€“ weâ€™re more used to LCD TVs these days. We enjoyed the very excellent bar on the top floor (36th floor) where the views were quite stunning. A good drinks menu, but we never had a full meal in the restaurant, preferring to eat out although we did enjoy a pizza on our first evening after an 11 hour flight as we were tired but not especially hungry; it was fine. Bar prices were not too expensive considering the status of the hotel and the location, so we used it quite a lot. We always found the staff to be very helpful and attentive. In all, an excellent stay and would definitely stay again.

The service at this hotel is performed graciously and precisely. The reservation staff went out of their way to make sure we were registered for their points program as they currently had a special promotion going on. All other personnel was firendly, gracious and expedient. The room was tastefully done,beds very combortable,temperature easily adjusted. The only comment might be that the hotel needs to upgrade to flat screen tvs in the rooms. Currently the outside facade is being rennovated and I believe there are plans to rennovate on parts of the inside.. Location is very cental on Union Square and very easy to start walking trips around San Francisco. Disliked the room tvs. Enjoyed the top floor dining room particularly the continental breakfast buffet and great view.

Location best thing about this hotel as it's right next to Union Square. Scaffolding up when we went but didn't affect our stay. Room fine. Bar and restaurant good. Concierge service good. If you can get good rate which we did then it's perfectly good enough, just don't expect to be wowed. Fine for city break.
Great view of bay, we loved upgrading to a club pass!

Ideally suited as a base to discover the city. Close to the shops, tour buses and car hire. The walk down to Fisherman's Wharf is a bit of a trek but well worth the effort as you walk through Chinatown and beyond. Breakfast was a little expensive but the service and the views were excellent. For a cheaper option - hop across the road to Starbucks, which has free wi-fi for the teenagers! Would definitely stay here again - the Bay View room was worth the upgrade.

Despite the expensive breakfast and internet access, this hotel is perfect: great location, since it is near of many interesting places; amazing views, mainly from the restaurant on 36th floor; and friendly staff.

This hotel is in a good location. Walking distance to union square, shopping, BART, restaurants etc. Felt very safe to walk around. Staff was very friendly. Check in was easy, no line and it was 4pm. We traveled with friends and asked to be put on the same floor. The hotel didn't have two rooms ready on the same floor. The bell desk took our luggage for storage and the front desk clerk told us it would be an hour. No problem, we went to get coffee, convenient location right across the street. 15 minutes later we received a phone call that our rooms were ready. The doorman are very helpful with directions, maps, recommendations and putting you in a taxi without waiting very long in the car. What really impressed me with the customer service was when we took a town car to the airport. At check in we realized that we left our laptop in the car. I called the hotel and told them what happened and was told they would check on it. 5 minutes later I was told the driver was on his way back to the airport to drop it off.

For staying in San Fran, you can't beat the location. It is close to everything: restaurants, bars, transportation, shopping, etc. This is an older hotel and the rooms definitely show the wear and tear. We got a good discount using the Costco rate; it would not have been worth it at all without the discount. BEWARE OF VALET PARKING: over $60 per night. Take the train to park elsewhere. The staff is friendly and mostly attentive. The rooms are laid out well, the bathroom had all the necessities and everything is clean. If you have stayed at a new Grand Hyatt recently, do not expect the same facility here...you could probably find a nicer room cheaper if you searched around at the boutique hotels. All in all, it was a good experience.

The Grand Hyatt is a large luxury hotel just off Union Square. Most of the San Francisco tourist sights are quickly reachable by buses or cable cars passing near the hotel. The Powell street BART station is just a few blocks away and provides an inexpensive way to reach the San Francisco International airport. Rooms are spacious and clean, and have all the luxuries you would expect from this class of hotel, but the TV in our room was a 25 inch tube, a vanishing beast. Our 8th floor room suffered from street noise, so ask for a higher floor if you need a quiet atmosphere. Our room had pay-for-use wired and wireless Internet, but the wireless signal was weak. The lobby space is pretty small and not the usual atrium like in the other San Francisco Hyatt on the Embarcadero. Grandviews lounge and restaurant on the 36th floor has a spectacular view of San Francisco Bay and reasonable prices given the location and class of hotel.

I had a six night stay wrapped around the Labor Day weekend and was pleasantly surprised with the Grand Hyatt. This was my first visit to San Francisco and choosing a hotel took some time and research. The location is terrific with easy access to all public transportation.(Get the muni pass; it is a tremendous bargain).The lobby was on the small side, but so what? It is very attractive and offers all the services you expect in a good hotel.Prompt, courteous staff with special mention going to the concierge desk. I reserved a bay-view, non-smoking room with a king-sized bed. I ended up in a room on the 26th floor that appeared to have undergone a fairly recent remodel. Extremely clean and very nicely furnished with a bed that was heaven on earth. If I have any "complaints", they are minor. The walls were a tad thin(heard the neighbors a few times), the exhaust fan in the bathroom didn't have a wall switch that I could find(got pretty steamy after a hot shower) and calling this a bay-view room was true but it would be better to call it a bay and city view room. Yes, I could see the bay but the majority of the view was of other buildings. The view was beautiful(especially at night) and I was not at all unhappy about it, but labeling it a bay-view room created expectations of an unobstructed view of the bay. In addition to the concierge staff, here are some more special mentions for this hotel:1) Iron and ironing board(very handy!!)2) Free daily newspaper3) Lots of upscale shopping nearby4) Wide variety(price and menu offerings) of restaurants nearby5) Theater district is also nearby6) Walgreens right around the corner for those items you forgot to pack7) Shuttle service to/from SFO a bargain at $16.008) Alarm clock on the night table as a back up for my cell phone alarm(don't laugh)9)Etc.................

We stayed at the Grand Hyatt for 2 nights. The hotel is in a great location - you're about 3 minutes away from Market Street, where you can hop on the MUNI and BART to pretty much anywhere in the city. It's right across from Union Sq and next door to Chinatown and the Cable Car lines. Plenty of eating and shopping options in the area as well. We booked the hotel through a priceline bid (about $100/night cheaper than the regular rates), but the staff person that checked us in (I think his name was Ryan) was friendly and welcoming nonetheless. The room looks worn out though - the tv, the carpet, the furniture all look like they need to be replaced soon. The bathroom also looks worn. But at least the room itself was clean (no bugs!) and the bed was very comfortable. I would probably stay here again just for its location but only if I could a discounted rate again - otherwise, there are probably better options out there.

This is a lovely hotel and would receive my recommendation to friends and family were it not for the bed bug bites my husband received staying there. On the second day of our stay, my husband noticed red welts on his arm. We reported the bites to the hotel staff and were moved to a new room. My husband spoke with a manager and maintenance man who inspected our old room. They claimed no evidence of a problem. I suppose my husband's bites weren't weighed as evidence. As a precaution against bringing pests home, we disposed of all the luggage and clothes we had brought into the room. I hope the hotel takes our report seriously and treats the room, but with the plethora of hotels available in San Francisco I would recommend staying elsewhere.

Rooms were dreary and dirty. Bathrooms definitely need updating. Musak in elevators is the most annoying I have heard in a long time. Staff were not friendly nor were they helpful. Definitely should not have a 4 star rating. Very over priced.

The location of the Grand Hyatt is very convenient, and the views from the bar & restaurant on top are great. Our bay-view room was smaller than the one we'd had at the St. Francis last summer, and our view was not quite as good (although some bay-view rooms would have truly fantastic views). Our room faced toward the financial district (which was actually rather attractive at night), with some views of the bay at the sides.  The few things that brought the hotel down a notch for me may not matter to others. The lobby was virtually non-existent, with nothing there but the check-in desk & concierge. No sundry shop, no gathering place, etc. I missed the feel and amenities of the St. Francis's lobby. The buffet breakfast, while in a room with a great view, was disappointing and sub-par (particularly the muffins and croissants). It's been a while since I've had croissants that bad. Aside from these things, I would have given the hotel 4 stars.

This hotel was great. It is very conveniently located. The lobby is so beautiful and the view from the rooms is awesome. Book a room with the regency club-the evening snacks and breakfast are a great deal and quite good. The fitness center is not great, but overall it is a nice place. The parking price is ridiculous, however ($50/day)

I stayed in the Grand Hyatt for a full week during August 2010 with some friends. While San Francisco weather was seasonably cooler than usual by about ten degrees, the staff at the Hyatt was warm and friendly (pardon the pun)! It was everyone's first time in the city and every morning when we went downstairs to begin our adventures, we would stop and ask the concierge for advice. Every day they were pleasant and incredibly helpful providing maps, public transportation information, ferry information, and even helped us plan a day trip to Muir Woods. Additionally, they were assisted in getting a car service to take my friends and I back to the airport for our VERY early flight home. They called to confirm the night before and called in the morning when the car had arrived. I cannot say enough wonderful things about the staff!!! The only negative would be the somewhat dated room furniture, but very clean and neat!

The location is perfect at Union Square, walking distance to the starting line of the race. Great restaurants everywhere, metro station to the airport a couple of blocks away. Check-in was like being interrogated by the KGB; my room had been booked under my friend's name and when the reservation had been made the hotel said all I had to do was change it to my name and credit card when I got there. My friend had even called the front desk that day to follow up and was told no problem everything would be taken care of when I got there. Then I got there and the story changed. At first the manager said "Oh we don't do that anymore" and told me I couldn't have the room as if I'm just going to say "OK", turn around, go back to the airport and fly 3,000 miles back home. I just kept standing there while he fussed and fretted around and I called my friend and asked her to call the manager and he finally relented and let me check in. The room was small which was ok because I don't take up much space but the first night (a weeknight) there was noise from the street like construction going on. My only real complaints were charging for Wi-Fi (a Marriott thing) and lack of electrical outlets--one in the bathroom and one under the little desk that I had to get down on my hands and knees to access. Laptop, ipod, cellphone, Bluetooth=4 outlets. The concierge was wonderful in getting me a 1-day car rental and had excellent written directions for getting out of the city. If you are driving in don't park in the hotel garage--drive around the hotel for a couple of blocks and shop around--I saw one garage that charged half of what Hyatt does.

I made my first trip to San Franscisco with my husband over the 4th of July weekend. The city is absolutely beautiful and there is so much to see and do there. The Grand Hyatt at Union Square is perfectly located. We were in the middle of it all: shopping, restaurants, and walking distance to some key attractions. We stayed on the club level which offered some great views. Although the hotel is due for renovations it was still nice and clean. It was obvious that although they haven't updated in a while they have maintained it fairly well. The club level lounge is a bit small but the service was good. The room and bathroom were a bit small and the bathrooms do not have separate showers. We would definitely stay there again, especially since renovations are under way.

We stayed for 5 nights at this hotel in mid-July 2010, and found the service and location to be exemplary. Front desk was incredibly helpful in helping us get delayed luggage from United (never trust United's SFO baggage dept). All requests for additional towels, pillows, were filled promptly. Location is terrific--2 minutes from the Chinatown arch entryway; around the corner from Union Square (with Macy's, etc.). Many mid-priced restaurants within 1-2 blocks (try Lefty O'Douls at 333 Geary st, diagonally across Union Square; they have full meals (cafeteria style) for $11 (!). Less than 15 minute walk to many major museums; easy access to BART and to Cable cars. Also, they offer 2 prices for parking--if you drive 1/2 block, they have a deal with a garage that offers 24-hour parking for $33; you can come and go (no extra charges for taking the car out and then returning/ it's all valet at the garage; we tipped $2 each time/ very quick). More expensive garage diagonally across the street but we're talking 25 yards v. 50 yards. Believe it or not, the $33 is actually a low rate for this area. The room was very comfortable; a bit on the small side (seems typical for SF); beds very comfortable. Top floor restaurant has great views and a very good buffet breakfast (not cheap, but nothing is). If you use the AAA rate, you get 2 breakfasts included.

The hotel design is great, sort of compact although it has amazing views from the top floor, where there is a bar, restaurant and meeting rooms. The manager, David, is a classy guy who takes pride in this property. He has an awesome golden retriever, Bailey.Shortcomings - a little noisy early in the morning - when dumpsters in the area are emptied. The sliding doors on the rooms could have better sound-proofing. Also, the windows needed cleaning. Strengths - location, ease of getting in and out, and to meeting rooms below, comfort of rooms, cleanliness of rooms, staff, spectacular views from the top.They staff was very friendly and helpful. They will be undergoing a huge renovation, and I look forward to visiting it again.

Great location, no problem with the service, speedy check in and never had to wait long for an elevator! Concierge was helpful on getting us Hop on Hop off tickets and also for telling us to get on the trolley at Saks instead of waiting 2.5 hours at the bottom of Powell St. BUT REALLY FOR A DOWNTOWN HOTEL OF THIS QUALITY HAVING OLD TVS AND CHARGING FOR INTERNET??? It seems the more expensive the hotel the more expensive the internet. Get flat screens and include the internet in the room rate.

The hotel needs a serious refresh. I was there for one night and I specifically asked for a non smoking room, I got a room that still had smels of smoke.The curtains had holes (probably from cigarettes burns) and there were stains on the lampshade. Not that I'm partciularily looking at this but it is not what I expect from a hotel of this category.

I know the economy is down, but the dey word here is wait. Wait to check in, wait for requests and when they say "we will get that right away" really means they will not respond. I had a request and they appropriately said "right away," one hour later nothing. I finally called back and there was no follow up. For these prices you would be better off in a full service hotel that offers just that full service.

Recommended by our travel agent who got us a very good price. We were very impressed with the size of the rooms (we had interconnecting rooms at a corner), the comfort of the beds and the overall arrangement. We did not use the facilities of the hotel very much, but the location was very good for getting anywhere in the city, especially the buses, cable cars and trolley buses. We used a cable car to get to the Alcatraz Cruises Pier and including the walk it took less than 30 minutes.

I stayed here with my family for four nights as part of a tour of the US. After a somewhat belated access to our room, at the 24th floor, we could enjoy the view of the Eastern part of downtown SF and the bay - just like we had requested.The room had an ok size, good beds - and a television from the last century... We did not watch anything else than a couple of weather forecasts, but a flat screen could save some space!The service of the hotel was, apart from the check-in, was excellent. However, in this class and price range, one could expect services as WiFi to be free. The $10 Ã¥lus charge per day seems both 'cheap' and out of date.The location at the NE corner of Union Sq is absolutely fantastic.The next time we go to SF, and we will!, our hotel research will have to come up with an absolute stunner to top this one.

We stayed at the Grand Hyatt for 2 nights and it was great. Typical Hyatt - nice service, check-in was friendly & quick, concierge was friendly and knowledgable about the area, and rooms were clean. It's a downtown Hyatt, so there is no parking (be prepared for the $45 overnight parking fee), and the lobby is crowded all day - but the location is in the heart of San Fran - 2 blocks from Chinatown - 1 block from Union Square - tons of restaurants and bars around. The top floor bar and restaurant offers one of the best views of the city day or night. If you're looking for a "boutique" or B&B type hotel expereince, don't stay here. Otherwise - this makes a great home base for San Fran exploring.
We stayed 2 days, driving to Napa and back on day 2. We wished we had stayed 2 nights in Bodega Bay instead. That was wonderful for about the same money.

This is the 3rd time I have stayed at this hotel and each time I have been happy. The rooms are clean and large for the city. The staff friendly and helpful. I love the location, right on Union Square and close to everything! Parking is expensive though there is a public parking lot close by that might be less expensive.

Stayed for 3 nights of our family vacation with our 3 children (17+ years old.) Got the AAA rate with breakfast included and used Hyatt dollars we bought at Costo for an extra 20% off so the price was great for two adjoining rooms. Enjoyed the buffet breakfast on the top floor with a great view. Chinatown was around the corner as were the shops of Union Square. Parking was pricey, but no more so than the other parking lots we checked. Room was clean and quiet, beds were cushy and big enough for my daughters to share comfortably. All in all, a perfect place to land after a day of sightseeing.

We stayed here while my husband was at a conference and we couldn't have been happier with the location and staff. All of the concierges were fantastic as were the staff in the Regency Club lounge. Outside of Asia, I have yet to see a club that surpasses this one. The food was terrific (and based on how long people were hanging out around the dinner hour, we weren't the only ones who made it into dinner!) and the staff truly exceptional. My only complaint was how dated the guestrooms were. Not dirty or worn but still in need of updating. But the staff was SO good that I am still giving it 4 stars. The management can rightly be proud of their staff - reading other reviews I see that lots of people agree with me - the staff makes this hotel!
Great location, staff was fabulous, bar/restaurant on top floor is nice with a great view, room price was reasonably priced as I was able to use a discount code. I would definitely stay here again!

The location was great but hardly worth the price. Lots of great food close by. Room and hotel were not anything more then your standard 4 star business hotel. The only thing I remembered was that hotel parking was outrageous - but as they say, when in Rome.

I spent 4 nights at the Grand Hyatt in San Francisco. It is a standard business hotel. The decor/furnishings throughout the hotel are very generic, and could use significant updating. The staff at the hotel, however, was exceptional. This was particularly the case of those who worked in the Grand Club (concierge level). I wouldn't be keen to recommend this hotel to those who want a more stylish venue. That said, it's not a bad backup if the price is right.

After a 14hour flight we checked in this hotel the staff was very friendly ,concierge was very helpful and we got a nice comfortable room though little small in size but clean. It is just one block from the Union square so the location is fantastic. Tram station is 2 minutes walk and there are couple of good restaurants close by. Buffet breakfast had a good spread and a good view of the city from the coffee shop

I really liked this hotel as I was having issues finding a nice hotel at a fair price around Union Square that being said I think the Grand Hyatt is the best value in Union Square. I thought the hotel was very clean and well decorated. The rooms are decent, wicked soft beds, the TV was horrific, and the bathroom was clean and fairly spacious. My only comment about the view is you get what you pay for... what I mean is that if you book on priceline, expedia, orbitz, etc.... they give you the base ho-hum room, but you have the option to PAY for a better view either on hyatt.com or at check-in and to have a view of the bay its like $30-50 more per night which I think is highway robbery, but if they make money on that than so be it.The parking is incredibly easy, there is a 24-hr valet garage less than half a block away on Sutter they charged me $32 a night which for the location in SF that is dirt cheap. However charging $10 internet is a hose job. You get a $15 voucher for breakfast at the rooftop restaurant which is nice. The breakfast is excellent and the view is even better. However, make sure you know the hours of breakfast service because I got hosed on Mother's day because they stopped serving an hour earlier then the guest book says and as I checked out a little later that morning I noticed on the desk the flyers saying something about a mother day brunch thing... regardless I had no clue of the hour changes because I checked in 4 nights ago and complained to the desk person and he took off the $40 (4 day) internet charge for my trouble. I was more upset about not being able to eat there because the food is so good and the view is wonderful.Another issue I had was loud and rowdy people in the hall at 1AM. A quick call to the front desk eliminated the noise problem within minutes. I heard the elevator chime within 30 seconds of the call hang up. Its nice that security is fast and prompt here. Overall I would stay there again, if I wanted to be in Union Square. Two small flies in the ointment wont dissuade me from staying here again.

Location wise it's a couple of miles from the main tourist ares but can walk and plenty of public transport options. Very close to the main shopping area though. Room was clean and comfortable. Bar and restaurant on top floor offers good value snacks, drinks and food and staff were very, very good. Concierge was excellent in helping with maps, excursions etc. Not ideal for kids but for couples on a city break or people on a business trip it offers a good standard and a reasoable price.

I have just spent 4 wonderful nights in the Grand Hyatt. You could not ask for a more centrally located hotel to go shopping, dining, chilling out in union square over a coffee and of course the cable car terminal. After a very long trip from UK to San Fran, we were greeted at the front desk by `Wayne`, who was very pleasant, courteous and exactly the right person to greet you after a long haul. Checking in was a breeze and after chatting about our trip we were given a room higher up on the 29th floor overlooking Union Square. Wow!! What a view. Thanks again Wayne.The rooms are very clean, tidy and the beds are comfortable. Our room had a mini-bar, TV, Alarm clock with i-pod docking and the usual iron, hair dryer and coffee making facilities. There is a room safe for your valueables, but if you want you can also get a box at reception.There is a good gym on the 35th floor with the usual runners/cycles and x-trainers as well as weight machines. The kit all looks modern and you can plug your i-pod into them or watch TV on the individual screen. It does get busy around 0700. The staff and concierge are very polite and accomodating. They sell tour tickets on the open top bus at a discounted rate, the bus is definitely worth doing to get your bearings and introduce you to all the districts, plus it stops outside the Grand Hyatt and goes over the Golden Gate bridge.A definite must is to go to the 36th floor for a drink or just to look out the panoramic window for a view of the bay and coit tower. We were fortunate to have great clear weather and had a fantastic view. Absolotely Wonderful.We decided to eat in the restaurant, the service is very good and the duty manager made sure everything was to the customers satisfaction. The starters were great, but I felt the main didn`t match up to the 1st course and I have to say I have eaten better for less $$, although those times are few and far between. However, it is definitely worth the experience of looking out onto San Fran enjoying a meal and cool glass of wine, watching the sun set over the horizon, a definite tick in the box thing to do. If you don`t want a big meal, they also do bar food in the bar area and a to-go service.I cannot fault the service and experience I had staying here, perhaps because I was on a high floor added to the experience, but I would definitely go back to the Grand Hyatt, if I were to return to San Fran.

One block off Union Square, this tall hotel is located in the core of the San Francisco shopping area. Having a small footprint, the lobby is efficient. There's no walking into this hotel and wondering where the front desk is. The concierge desk is manned by multiple people as befitting the demand for information at this location. The staff was uniformly helpful and friendly, providing solid timely advice on what to see, do, and how to get places. Bell, housekeeping and front desk staff were helpful and friendly without crossing the line to annoying or smarmy. We had a standard room on the floor with the club lounge. The lounge is well staffed and has excellent views Northward with no building blocking.The room itself was clean and offered sufficient room for the two of us. The bed was comfortable if a little firm. It was... a room. I stay in 70 or so hotel rooms a year and to be honest, this one was more or less average. That is not bad as I stay at Hyatt a lot for a reason (in fact I'm in one on the other side of the globe from SF as I write this review). It was a good room with good temperature control, but it really shines in comparison to those of the other upper end Hyatt product in central SF.We've been to SF many times. It is our getaway city. This was the first time we'd stayed at the Grand Hyatt and I'm happy to say that it won't be our last. Dependable, clean, helpful, friendly, and safe, everything you want in a downtown core hotel, the Grand Hyatt provides it to a consistently high standard. We will certainly be back.

The room was spacious and clean, the bed was comfortable, and the location was convenient. Unfortunately, there wasn't much sound-proofing, so we had a lot of noise from the neighbors and the hallway. Also, I had called in advance to request a room with a view of the bay, but we got a view of the parking lot next door. When I called the front desk to ask about switching, they were rude about the fact that I had bid on Priceline. All in all, it was worth it because I got a good deal, but had I paid full price I would have been very disappointed by the noise, view, and service.

Pros: Great location, nice room view (but average size), top floor restaraunt/bar views of city were amazing. Food was good, but not great. Paid $179 for room - seems 'fair' but am sure other good options out there, too. Overall nice Hyatt quality comes at a steep price with hidden fees (see below)Cons: Hyatt will "rape" you in various charges and fees. Like charging $55 dollars for overnight car parking. Or $10 dollars for daily Wi-Fi connection. And if you use their in room phone to the tune of like $3 dollars a minute. It's straight up theft. I complained to management for a $60 dollar charge for 20 minute call and they seemed oblivious. I tried watching an in room movie VOD and the picture quality was terrible, too. Also, my room was near elevator shaft and I could hear the roar of the elevator in the bathroom sometimes.Was I satisfied overall? Yes. Would I stay there again? Probably not.

My husband was taking a class in town, so we stayed for four nights and five days. This hotel, I thought, would be much more grand and the rooms a little fancier - everything about it was just average. I told the woman at the front desk that we were newlyweds, hoping for something cozy, and we ended up with a room facing the back of two other buildings. It was nothing like what I expected after seeing other reviews raving about the view. No view at all, even though the hotel was not exactly full. I would never pay the rates they want - which must be due to the proximity to Union Square. And they are "steps away from Chinatown" but also border an area of town that isn't very nice. I'm recommending only because I have friends who would love to be as close as this is to all of the stores.

The hotel was easy to find and right on Union Square. As far as location goes I donâ€™t have any complaints. We pull up in front of the hotel and stop in the valet parking area. Kindly the valet attendant notified us of the daily parking rate and also a secondary parking location with a cheaper daily rate (not ran by the hotel). The secondary parking structure was around the corner. I didnâ€™t feel like driving anymore so I stayed with the original hotel valet and paid the extra $15 bucks a day. Checking in was seamless..Only a few people in line with plenty of staff to help out. The grand lobby area was not so impressive; maybe Iâ€™m becoming a snob because my last hotel stay was in the Bellagio in Las Vegas. Anyways, nothing really impressive about the entry way, but nonetheless we were on our way up to the room quickly.We booked one of the "club level" rooms with a view of the bay. Well, the room was very, very small for a semi suite. Yes, I do understand that San Francisco typically has small rooms, but that's way I paid the extra money to enjoy a little more room with some relaxing views. The bathroom was small and pretty standard, nothing to brag about. The television was probably a 27-inch tube style. The least you could do is pull out these old style TVâ€™s...donate them while they're still working and spend a couple hundred bucks for some nice flat screens. At least they should do that for the suites. The furniture seemed a little outdated...come to think of it the whole interior of the hotel seemed a little outdated. The view...yes we did see the bay, but it was hindered by the view of the roof tops on the nearby buildings. Not quite the enjoyable view I imagined, besides there wasn't any room to sit down and take it all in. After a quick relaxation on the bed we decided to go upstairs and enjoy some hors dâ€™oeuvres (not sure if I spelled that correctly) in the lounge specifically for "club level" guest. Again, nothing to really brag about here...the food was typical and nothing exciting. Only 1 television tucked away in the corner where only 2 tables could view it. At least the TV here was a decent size maybe a 40-inch LCD. I was able to catch some highlights of the NBA playoffs. The bar was an "honor" bar; basically you make your own drinks, fill out a card specifying how many and have it charged to your room. Not a bad choice of drinks...there was enough options to satisfy your thirst, also the soft drinks, water and coffee was free. After, leaving the lounge we decided to relax a little more before trying the hotel restaurant boasting of beautiful views. The bed was a little stiff and the sheets were standard, maybe a 200 thread count. After a little cat nap we started getting dressed and to my surprise, I canâ€™t seem to find a power outlet. The power outlets were all behind the night stand, the bed or the table. The table was easiest to get to but had several items plugged into it (coffee maker, telephone, lamp, TV). After crawling under the table to plug in the iron I noticed that there was an available outlet on the base of the lamp. That was the only outlet available in the whole entire room (besides the bathroom). Although, this was a leisure trip, I still work on my laptop; charge my cell, etc. etc. With this set-up I was only able to do one at a time. One plus was the iron itself...I'd have to say it was a great iron. A kinda funny giving prop to an iron, but it was worth mentioning. Ah the restaurants...nothing spectacular, not even the views. The food was sub-par but the drinks were poured nicely. Service was decent and the food was brought out in a timely manner. The views of the city lights were ok, but nothing to brag about. The price of the food was a little steep, but that was kind of expected. Walking out of the restaurant we passed a piano lounge/bar. It was very crowded, and people seemed to be enjoying themselves. We decided to hit the streets of SF instead. The fitness center was pretty much what you need in a fitness center. Had all the basicsâ€_treadmills, stationary bikes, dumbbells, resistance machines and televisions. I used the treadmill for awhile and the resistance machines without incident. Towels and water was readily available. Check out was just as seamless as check in. We paid our additional expenses and in our vehicle within 5 minutes. Overall not a bad stay, but we were expecting a little more. Hope this helps.Thanks!

The Grand Hyatt was in a great location, right at the edge of Union Square. Itâ€™s about a block away from a cable car stop, which is very convenient. You can walk to some of the popular tourist spots, but it would be a long walk, especially with the all the hills in San Francisco. The hotel was clean and nice, but not overly luxurious. It was definitely a little dated, but still comfortable. The service from everyone we encountered was very friendly and helpful.

I was pleasantly surprised by this hotel. From some of the reviews I expected a tired old property in need of renovation. This was not the case. The rooms are a bit on the small side but that is to be expected in the city. They are tastefully decorated. The bathroom appeared to have been redone fairly recently. Overall the room was clean and comfortable. The location and views cannot be beat. Enjoy your stay.

Whilst its true the hotel is due for refurbishment (front desk said the gradual process was to start late 2010) I found the room and the furnishing to be quite acceptable and the bed, the most important thing in the room, was huge, incredibly comfortable and the bedding fresh clean and of high quality - resulting in a great night's sleep.The staff were all great - friendly and enthusiastic - from front desk, to doormen to the executive lounge staff. The breakfast there was adequate in quantity and quality, but get there early for the view! Free wifi is available in the lounge too, though it closes early at 2100.Location has been enthused about before, and the view from my room was stunning, it has to be said.

I can't say enough about the great experience my friend and I had at the Grand Hyatt.The room was more than adequate, the good rate included breakfast (anything on the menu), parking was a bit expensive but we received a 25% discount. Only negative was to pay for internet - in this day and age - guests should receive free internet. This amenity is free from a Best Western to a Bed & Breakfast, why not at a large hotel chain? The staff, from the doorman, to the bellman, front desk, concierge, and wait staff went out of their way to be accommodating and upbeat.

We stopped over for two nights in San Francisco to do a college tour for our teenage son after spending several days in Monterey. This was our third straight year we have stayed at the Grand Hyatt while visiting the city and our fourth stay overall.As usual we walked almost everywhere, to the Westfield Mall and the Powell Street BART station, North Beach, the Financial District and over to the Ferry Building. We requested a room on the Gold Passport Floor and received access to the Regency Lounge located on the 32nd floor. This is a great place for a light breakfast in the morning and we enjoyed juice, hot coffee, fresh fruit and muffins on our last day there. This was a lot less stressful than standing in line for an hour to have breakfast at one of the small and popular cafes at the edge of the Tenderloin which we did the previous day.Service from the front desk, concierge, bellmen, the host at the Regency Club and room staff was professional and courteous. I noticed that the door and bellmen kept a close but discrete watch of people entering the lobby area, which I really appreciated and took as a sign of additional security for the hotel guests. We checked out early but asked the hotel to hold our luggage until it was time to go out to the airport. I liked that they placed our bags in a secured area off the lobby and asked us to go in with them to point out our luggage, insuring everything we stored came out.We enjoyed our short stay here and are pleased with the level of accommodations, location and service we received. There may be nicer, more luxurious properties and expensive properties to stay at in San Francisco, but we are comfortable with the Grand Hyatt and intend to return on our next visit.

For the price I could not complain really; I've seen this property at it's best in years past. Stayed this time for a great rate found through my travel agent. Fantastic location, dated hardware. Personnel could be more personable really. Nothing horrible. Concierge (Elaine) was fantastic - she has been there for years as i recall. Beds comfortable. Rooms clean. Great views from Grand View bar. Restaurant reallllly lacks. Furniture is very worn and tired. It's time the owners of this property face the music and dump the milliions in this property required to bring it up to 2010. SF has so many cute and nice hotels in this area next time I will ask for recommendations of boutique nature - this occassion was more about affordability.

Made reservations for two rooms for two couples a month in advance using a coupon that included a discounted price of $150 and free breakfast. Recieved perfect e-confirmation of reservation. Arrived first and front desk was unable to find the reservation and did not want to honor coupon. Front desk even suggested that I go somewhere??? and print out my confirmation, even though I had the confirmaiton number!!!, and come back. Finally remade the reservation for both rooms and the front desk agreed to honor the coupon. Went up to room: shower head broken, light bulb burned out, coffee maker broken. These things were fixed the next day. When our friends arrived the front desk could again not find the reservation and hassled them out of the coupon for a room. After three days we left, checking over the bill we were charged for beer we never drank out of the room bar, a movie we never watched, and the breakfast that was supposed to be included. My boyfriend paid a corrected bill. Our friends paid for their room. A week later I saw a $300 charge on my credit card and called the Grand. Apparently I was charged for no-showing on the original reservation!!!! Incredible as it sounds, it took me two weeks and three phone calls to fix. Ughhhhh!
I was there to attend a red carpet event. The BAFTA awards!! Well this place was real grand and luxurious!

I had a good time at this hotel, with only one complaint, the noise! The rooms are very clean, the beds are incredibly comfortable, and the staff are truly friendly. My only compaint was noise coming from a party of drunken/high guests in the next room. The staff was very accomodating of my concerns, and I would be happy to stay here in the future. Also, this hotel is very expensive for the quality, if you purchase your room at the published price. Check around the discount sites, and you should be able to find it at a much lower rate. ** Be Sure to Check Out the Bar on the Top Floor, Great View of the Bay! **

Loved it. Were treated like royalty the entire time. Hotel is in perfect location. Customer service is A+. Check out hotel on the top floor. Amazing view of the city and harbor including Alcatraz. Pillows and bed are incredibly comfy- hard to get out of bed! Try the room service..amazing. Nothing but great things to say about this place. Luxury, luxury, luxury.
We liked the Grand Hyatt. It was recommended to us by our travel agent.

This is a very good location near Union Square. As a Hyatt Diamond, I was given some nice amenities promptly after check-in. Our room was very small, but that's what I'd expect in a SF hotel. The view was amazing, it was a beautiful view of Union Square and the big Christmas tree there. The lounge upstairs was always very crowded, and it was hard to even find a seat. The selection of snacks and drinks was pretty good, though. The view from the lounge was also very nice. For the price of the hotel, I thought it was only an average value. I will want to try a different hotel for my next visit to SF, but I would not be opposed to staying here again.

We just got back from a three-day weekend trip to the Grand Hyatt San Francisco, and this was the best hotel experience we've had in quite some time. The room was comfortable, the location unbeatable, and the staff incredible. We arrived early on Saturday; I'd requested early check-in, but knew that showing up at 9:30am was really pushing it. However, it was no problem at all; we were checked in right away, with the requested view. The room was on the smaller side, and the two armchairs felt unnecessary and cramped, but it was nothing a little reorgnaizing couldn't fix. Grandviews restuarant for breakfast and take-out for lunch was excellent. Very good food for a reasonable price, and top-notch service. The bellmen staff were always attentive and friendly. We got a great deal directly through the Hyatt site, and I would certainly recommend this hotel as a great place for a couple on a weekend away; location is really great and within a five or ten-minute walk of great shopping and delicious restaurants. We were with our young son, and it was also perfect for a young family. He had the time of his life, as did we, and we can't wait to return!
This hotel is exhausted. The rooms are dirty, everyhting is old and is desperately in need of an extensive upgrade. Only the Concierge was good.

Grand Hyatt San Francisco, a hotel in the hearth of San Francisco, very close to China Town, no need to have a car, perfect conexions with local public traffic. If you like to go to Napa Valley then you need a car or a tour.

The hotel is comfortable, nice layout downstairs/easy to navigate around, good customer service and great location. Parking/TransportaionI suggest using public transportation or taxi and not drive yourself The 'space' holds no more than 7 cars and is a shared taxi stand with poor signs and costs about $50/dayRoomsThe rooms are clean & quiet, but very small and need remodeling. They are fine for a single business traveler. The beds are comfortable which is a plus.ServiceFront desk staff and concierge were great. The bell/bag staff appeared lazy and took me effort to get their attention to hold our bags while we went to breakfast. Definatlely not a warm and friendly feel.

I've stayed at the Grand Hyatt Several times since I get a special nightly rate there because of my job. I choose this hotel most of the time because of its location. It's located right on Union Square, across the street from Niketown. There's also a Starbucks across the street and Macy's and all the fashionable upscale stores (Tiffany's, LV, Gucci, etc...) are within 5-10 minute walking distance. Most importantly, there are tons of restaurants in this part of town. The Grand Hyatt is about a 10-15 cab ride to Fisherman's Wharf.As far as the room, the beds were comofortable and I had a very good night's sleep. The room was very clean and did not notice anything out of the ordinary. Like any upscale hotel, they overcharge with the items in the mini-bar.Peoples main complaint is the parking, which is $50 per night, valet only. Unfortunately, parking is expensive for ALL hotels in SF not just the Hyatt. If you want to save money, I suggest parking down the street at a parking garage for about $25 per night. I was fortunate to find street parking, since the meters are not running on the weekends.Lastly, I recommend checking out the bar at the top floor of the hyatt. You have an incredible view of San Francisco, and you jaw will drop because of this view while you're having a martini.

I traveled to SF to see the renovated California Academy of Sciences. I used to live in the Bay Area, so when I visit SF I tend to have a singular purpose. I don't spend a lot of time wandering the streets like a tourist, although I still like to window shop. This hotel is in a nice location near a lot of good shopping and convenient to BART and the cable car. My room had an excellent view of the Bay, Coit Tower, the Bay Bridge, and the TransAmerica Building. It was a picture postcard view and was the highlight of my stay. Otherwise, the room was rather small and uninspired. The bathroom could use a remodel. The clock radio did not work, which was annoying to us both because we wanted to hear music and because we wanted the alarm. The hotel lacked charm and glamour. At this price point you might not be able to do too much better, but if you can spend a little more you can get more elsewhere. Be warned that parking here may set you back as almost much as the room itself. It cost me $50 to park each night and after factoring in taxes my $120 room became a $200 room and that was without room service. For $200 I would stay elsewhere, but if you are a tourist without a car it's not a bad deal. We walked over to the Four Seasons for breakfast just to see what that was like and we weren't impressed, but I'm sure it was better than Hyatt's overpriced offerings. I had an excellent experience in the past with the concierge at this hotel and I want to remark that the front desk staff did a good job on this visit. They allowed me to check-in very early (and very efficiently). The valets took some time to retrieve my car and my experience with them was spotty. Overall, it was an acceptable stay but I felt it was not a great value. If not for the superb view I would have been miffed.

I really wanted to love the Grand Hyatt in San Francisco. The location is fantastic. The staff was so friendly, helpful and welcoming. The city view from our room was lovely. But the rooms...ugh. Really tired and shabby. There were weird stains on the lampshades, holes in the curtains, scuffs all over the walls. The room was comfortable, just really rough around the edges and worn out. Also, when we checked out there were a lot of people waiting for their cars outside and we were told it would take up to 1/2 hour to get our car from the valet. It didn't actually end up taking quite that long for us, but there were others still standing there who'd been waiting before we were. Considering there is a huge parking garage (much cheaper) at the corner of Stockton and Sutter, we could have parked the car ourselves and walk across the street. I would only consider staying here again if the hotel undergoes a renovation. There are way too many other great places to stay in the city for this price.

As a Hyatt Platinum member I stay at many Hyatt properties (as well as many other hotels). This was my first visit to this property - and likely my last. After a delayed check-in, seemingly caused by not enough desk personnel, I got to my room. The carpet was worn (poorly repaired) and soiled. The furnishing were very worn - and clearly not up to Hyatt standards. When I shared my complaint the hotel staff that responded were concerned and seemed to understand the problem. I was told that there would be a complete renovation of the hotel in the next six months. So, check if you're considering this property to see if the renovations have been completed. If not, stay elsewhere.

Perfect for what we needed, a nice clean hotel in a good location. We stayed 2 nights book-ending a trip to Sonoma. We had concierge level which is always nice and the lounge was very comfortable with nice cheese/cracker/wine selections for cocktail hour and delicious breakfast selections. A very comfortable couch and private business center with free internet access. The rooms themselves were very comfortable, nothing too special but what you'd expect for a GH. We did have a nice view from the top floors and I did appreciate all of the extra mirrors in the room aside from the one in the bathroom. The fitness center was above average for a hotel in my opinion with plenty of new cardio machines, weights and mats etc. We also checked out the restaurant/bar on the top floor at night which was a spectacular view on a clear evening.One downside was there was no gift shop in the hotel selling snacks/toiletries/magazines. I guess they want people to buy stuff from the mini bar, but I think they should offer that even for a bottle of water. We arrived later in the evening one night and there was no options and no vending machines on any of the floors. Annoying.

First timer at GRAND HYATT, and it was a very nice stay. Arrived when there were multiple conferences/conventions going on with most everyone of them already checked-in ... so expecting the worst of rooms. Had requested a high floor room, and the super nice front desk (Wayne?!) did some searching, and was able to find one. Nice ! Here are my assessments:LOCATION: Right on Union Square shopping. Shopper's heaven! Very close to Chinatown, restaurants, and cable car stops. Reasonable reach for everything else.ROOM: Great view on the 30th floor, overlooking city ... facing SF bay, Coit Tower, Transamerica building, etc.... very nice. (2) comfortbale double-beds, including desk with coffee maker, side chair, TV armoire, and minibar/fridge. Need to update TV however ... from the dark ages. Curiously, no chair for the desk... a minus. In-room safe as well as all standard toiletries for bathroom. Very roomy closet.DECOR: Nice, basic, expected decor for a Grand Hyatt. Lobby was very convention-y and somewhat cold (appearance wise). No large seating area, and somewhat small ... which filled up with people quickly from the conferences, etc..SERVICE: A++ PERFECT front desk personnel. Worked on the room requested, and got it. Very friendly, conscientious, and even called to room ... just as I arrived, to make sure everything was ok. Did not use bellhop, valet, concierge or room service to assess. No complaints here at all.OVERALL: Would I stay here again? Yes. I would recommend it, given its convenience to all, comfortable, clean rooms, and wonderful, friendly service.

This hotel was incredible. It is located in the heart of San Fransisco next to China Town, amazing shopping and restaurants. The service was great and rooms were luxurious. Everything was very clean and extravagant. Though the rooms were great with comfy beds, there were not a lot of accommodations provided. Internet was an additional cost, no fridge and no breakfast.

This is a big city hotel. It is hard to unload from as there is little room to pull in, so it suits airline passengers more I would imagine.It has wonderful staff who open doors for you, but the rooms are very dated, the bathrooms particularly.We had awful trouble with our billing at this hotel too, where the credit cards were credited and debited over and over for no apparent reason which was annoying.I can't help feeling a little ripped off in a hotel like this where you pay top rates for the rooms, then pay for internet, parking and ridiculously high prices for room service.Everything was as it should be service wise, it was just lacking that special something.I would probably recommend you find a smaller boutique hotel instead.

Good location and helpful staff but the hotel seems outdated. Elevators need to be upgraded. Bath tub was clogged but problem was resolved quickly by maintenance. The rooms were quite small and dated. $35/day parking. Don't expect too much for this Grand Hyatt.

Yes the walls are thin, I really heard a neighbor's phone ringing and her answering it, also people walking down hall. Windows are large, but not sound tight. The room was outdated and there was no robe or other sundries in room. No free wifi, bed was slopey and mediocre. The concierge was not too helpful and the lounge staff would not seat you in the part with the nice view at 10 am because it was "for lunch." What? Did not feel like we were at a posh hotel. This was not what I was expecting from a 4 star! PS, if you decide to stay here, park at the Union Square garage yourself and save $15 (It's $48 for the valet to park it there for you vs $32 for 24 hours to do it yourself--SAME PLACE.)

whenever I travel I like the Hyatt brand worldwide. This hotel is in a great location right on union square. but it is tired. the rooms are outdated and relly the whole site needs a revamp.the club lounge is about 10x too small. it simply cannot handle the number of guests. when you compare this lounge to that in the GH Hong Kong, they just do not compare.

One star because I have to, dedicated to the staff at the Grandviews lounge who are polite and friendly and gave somewhat of a Hyatt style service.The reason for the bad review is the same as other Yelpers: paper thin walls. Last night (yes, NYE no less) the four of us returned to my friend's hotel room after the bars has shut down for a little sparkling wine and to chat. Even just having a discussion at a normal level (no whooping, hollering, loud laughter) was enough to have someone banging on the door and security showing up to tell us to be quiet!Not Hyatt quality, certainly not Grand Hyatt level.Don't stay here unless you plan on whispering past midnight...

I stayed at the Grand Hyatt for three nights immediately prior to Thanksgiving.My flight from Australia arrived at 10:30 am and I went straight to the hotel from the airport. I was able to check in immediately and was given a room on the 11th floor overlooking Union Square. The good sized room had a standard layout. Wardrobe (with personal safe) and separate drawer space were perfectly adequate. Bathroom fittings were fine, with good quality towels, soap, shampoo, toothpaste etc. There was plenty of hot water (with good water pressure) at all times.The bed and especially the pillows were extremely comfortable. The TV was located in an armoire and provided a good choice of channels.The hotel has 6 elevators, which means that guests never have to wait long when either ascending to the rooms or descending to the lobby. A very big plus in my book.The location of the hotel in Stockton Street is ideal. Market Street is a short walk away and leads the dedicated shopper past numerous department stores. The closest street car is a block away. I didnâ€™t have a car and was able to get round the city either on foot or on public transport.All the staff I encountered at the Grand Hyatt couldnâ€™t have been more pleasant. I will definitely stay there again on a future visit to San Francisco.

We booked this hotel a month in advance thinking of it to be in perfect location and excited to get the "Hyatt" experience. We were in for a shocking surprise. This hotel is very old and not at all well maintained. We were given a room next to the laundry service even though repeatedly asking for a room with a nice view. The rooms are too small(which is okay considering the hotel location) and old. The closet door and desk chair were broken(door came out when we tried to open it). The bathroom looks like one in a roadside motel with a constant stinking smell coming from the drains. At one point water came out of the bathtub drain.  We were going to stay there for 3 nights but could not bear more than 1 night. We moved to the nearby Omni hotel which is few blocks away where we got a master suite for half the price. Omni experience was something else: huge rooms, amazing service, great luxurious bathrooms and good location too. Why waste money in a dump when you can get a great hotel for half the price?Definitely not worth a 4 star.

Got a great deal on Priceline two days in advance of our annual black Friday boondoggle. This location just cannot be beat. It is one half block up from Union Square. The lobby was busy when we arrived with people coming and going-they had several doormen and valets on duty. Even though we arrived at a busy time and two hours ahead of the scheduled check in we were immediately greeted and given our room. The front desk was very, very gracious and accomodating of the fact that I had accidently shown up with no credit card in my wallet!!  As we waited for the elevator, we noticed a lady really struggling to get out of the elevator with a really big rolling suitcase. An employee jumped in out of nowhere to help her and asked others if they needed help. Very nice-I love to see people make extra effort when it comes to service. The lobby is nothing exciting. It's long and narrow, the front desk is to the right as you enter and the elevators to the left. Behind the elevators is a small seating area which they had decorated for the holidays.  Our room was on the 21st floor. We looked out to the Westin St. Francis (my daughter was fascinated by their outside elevators), the Sir Francis Drake Hotel and Starlight Room and the tiny peek of Union Square. When I book rooms on bidding sites. . I expect to get one of the "lesser rooms", that's fair enough. But this room did not seem to be sub-par in anyway. It was spacious and clean and I liked the location on a high floor. We were right next to the housekeeping closet and expected to have some noise from that in the morning, but that did not happen. They are either very quiet or it's a little used closet. The bed was super comfortable with nice linens. If you were there on a more extended stay, there was plenty of room to put your things. A spacious closet, two dressers. TV is in an amoire with a Mini bar/fridge - the sensor kind so you can't use the fridge for your own stuff. There's a desk and chair and a small sitting area with arm chair and table by the window. Liked the iPod docking port. The ONLY thing about the room that wasn't perfect is, as others have mentioned, the furniture is a little banged up.The only storage in the bathroom is the countertop. Nice, Portico brand white ginger soap and shampoo and a little tube of toothpaste!  We didn't eat at the Grandview on the 36th floor but went up to look at it and it was BEAUTIFUL with a spectacular view!! We would have had a drink in the bar but it was full. I would recommend this hotel for service, cleanliness, spacious room and awesome location. Especially if you get the $66 price tag that we did!! Have fun!

I attended a conference at the Hilton but chose this place for lodging. Having membership with both, I found Hyatt treats Gold Passport members a little better than Hilton treats HHonors members.There is much to like about this hotel: A great central location; Walgreen's is next door; 24-Hour Fitness is three blocks east; Good department stores are close by; This is a high rise building so the views from the restaurant, club level and rooms on the upper floors are equally incredible from all directions; The hotel staff is courteous and well trained; The Grand Club concierges are extremely accommodating; The Hyatt Grand Bed is very comfortable; and The showers have good water pressure.Although some other bloggers have commented about the hotel being â€œdated,â€ù the Grand Hyatt still felt a bit more upscale than the Hilton. The Hilton guest rooms felt like a Vegas hotel at the bad end of the strip.A few small things I didnâ€™t like: Old fashion TVs; Bathrooms with dated and claustrophobic standard tub/shower combo (A curved shower rod would be a relatively inexpensive fix); The $25 breakfast buffet with no omelet station... nope, canâ€™t even special order an omelet from the kitchen... particularly vexing since the Hyatt Fishermanâ€™s Wharf (20 blocks to the north) has a breakfast buffet complete with omelet station for $18. Whatâ€™s up with that? Be warned, the valet is very, very slow. At $55 per day for valet parking, this was unacceptable! Also, prepare to take a cab ride for good food. Dining choices near the hotel are limited and unremarkable.Other tips: Request upper floors to get away from street noise and upgrade to the club level if possible. If you want to a break from the $30 to $50 per person dinner checks typical in SF, Tommyâ€™s Joint is a great â€œdownscaleâ€ù option for good food. It is located at Van Ness and Geary, about at a 15 minute walk west of the hotel. It is a barbeque/sports bar thatâ€™s been in continuous operation since 1947. You can eat well for less than $10/person.Overall, I still give the highest rating because the staff at Grand Hyatt San Francisco treats guests so well. Like our â€œGovernatorâ€™ says: â€œIâ€™ll be back!
Nice hotel with regard to rooms and fitness service offered. But no free wireless Internet, not even in the hotel lobby!!

This is 'the hotel' for our trips to San Francisco. 1) Location is the best ( we love Union square, but 5-10 minutes walk from Market can easily spoil the pleasure. Hyatt is located right at the Union sq.) ); 2)Staying with Hyatt garanties above-average level of service and comfort, 3) We love the bar on top floor: view is unbeatable and even food last time was really good and fresh. Rooms vary, some are nice, some are ok. Our last room was just 'ok', but had a million $ view. Since this is in the downtown, it can be noisy, even at night ( we kind of enjoy it as a part of city atmosphere).

Booked and paid for a bay view room. The room itself was good, although they need updating, the bay view was small patches of water in between buildings.Paid extra for the club lounge, this really was hit and miss. Come afternoon tea/dessert they would have ONE cake delivered for the whole club and (so we were told) were not allowed any more, so if you arrived ten minutes after it arrived there was nothing except a few pretzel sticks. Breakfast was basic fare and evening canapes were minimal and lacking in quality. The hotel is very well positioned, the front desk staff friendly and accommodating.Wouldn't stay here again, as it has been said before, there are many more hotels better than this.

I booked this hotel via a discount website and was extremely happy with the value. The room had a nice view and was comfortable for 3 adults. There were no noise issues and the view of Embarcadero was nice. The beds were comfortable and the room was clean. We had to request additional towels but delivery was prompt. We didn't eat at the hotel but entertainment and restaurants were within walking distance. The touristy area is about a mile away but we didn't have any safety issues and walking that far was refreshing due to its proximity to the bay. The management was nice enough to allow a very late checkout and I did not have any additional fees added to my bill.

We recently stayed at the Grand Hyatt in San Francisco for a four day weekend get-a-way. I was quite pleased with most aspects of the hotel although it is showing signs of wear and could use a bit of freshening up. We stayed on the 33rd floor in a Club King room with access to the Club Lounge on the 32nd floor. Our room was small but very clean and the comfortable and the view was fantastic. Access to the club lounge brings with it a contintental breakfast, afternoon snacks and evening desserts. Sodas, bottled water and sparkling water is available from 6 am to 9 pm at no additional cost. There is also a computer with printer available for use at no fee. The view from the lounge is also fantastic with a clear view of the bay.The staff of the hotel is extremely friendly and helpful. We did not try the restaurant or lounge on the 36th floor but I would definitely stay there again. It's location is perfect for access to Chinatown, Nob Hill, nearby shopping, Market Street, restaurants etc.

The doormen give the hotel a plush sort of feeling to it. Kind of a priviliged feeling there. Liked the conference room. Had an internet room, that charged about six dollars to use the internet for about 15 minutes at a time. Busy, busy hotel. The room service was above and beyond what I expected in a hotel. I wasn't feeling well that day and they seemed to cater to me even more. They have a nice, nice restaurant on the top of the building and you can see quite a bit of San Francisco from there. The food was delicious and the waiters were very kind and accommodating. Busy front desk. We went to Fisherman's Wharf, which we had to take a taxi from our hotel to get there. Interesting to see and seeing the view of Alcatraz was surreal. Didn't take the tour to Alcatraz, but did take a bus tour and had a wonderful tour of the city with a great tour guide. I don't know that I would care to revisit San Francisco, though the shopping around the hotel seemed pretty awesome, with many designer named stores. We visited Chinatown, which was walking distance from the hotel and which is intriquing to see. My reason for not desiring to see San Francisco again is that people seemed rushed there, which is not a comfortable environment to walk into when you are travelling.. I did hear though that if we had time that we should have seen the surrounding San Francisco area, the bay area and the wine country. The hotel was a nice retreat to return to vs. the rushed environment outside of the hotel.

We went to a confrence as I had not visited San Francisco for about 10 years. We were pleasantly surprised with the Grand Hyatt. We arrived about 10 am in hopes of checking in early, I was guessing we would be declined until 2pm , but the front desk stepped it up and were very cordial to let us check in, After a bad flight it was nice to kick back and relax. The rooms are small so it takes a bit of getting used to but we chose to explore the city instead, This property sits on Union Square so there is plenty to do with in walking distance. We went to Fishersmans Wharf one of the days and its worth doing, The old cable cars are a hoot and cheap too. The down side of FW is that there are tons of panhandlers that are very agressive. We didnt see any of SFPD in the 4 hours we were there.A little wierd but thats what SF is. Plenty of tee shirt and gift stores with several restaurants. ( My wife was pleased to buy a knockoff Prada purse for 35 bucks!)
Great location!Extremely clean!Little bit out-of-date ....

We stayed for 3 nights for the PGA Presidents Cup at the Grand Hyatt. We were very happy with the hotel and especially liked the location. We did not have a car and were able to ride the BART from the airport and walk the short way to the hotel. We were also able to easily catch a cab from the hotel if we wanted to, but we also walked to the wharf. We had a good dinner at the Grand Views restaurant with a beatiful sunset to go with it. We had a great time watching Fleet week airshows, touring on the segways and biking the Golden Gate bridge. (we opted for the electric bikes-only way to go). The weather was great part of the time and freezing the rest of the time-darn it. It was a great weekend and alot of fun at the golf tourney on Sunday. We will definately go back to SF and we will probably stay at the Grand Hyatt again next time.

Just my thoughts: The hotel was ok, not too great for being a Hyatt.-Valet parking is $50 overnight, and you have to wait for max 1/2 hour for your car to arrive.-The bar on the 36th floor closes at 1 pm, but stops serving food at 12. -There isnt a fan in the bathroom so the mirrors steam upon the other hand...-there was hot water-the beds were really comfy-prime spot..peferct for walking everywhereOther than that it was ok, your not really in the hotel too much so I can't complain. I just thought it would be better since its a Hyatt...

We've stayed at the Grand Hyatt 5 or 6 times, the most recent over Labor Day weekend. We are local, but when we go to the City and stay at the Hyatt it's like we are a thousand miles away. As many posters have said, the location is perfect right in Union Square, close to all shops and many great restaurants. The hotel itself is very nice and we generally stay on the club level which gives us access to their private lounge. Very nice for breakfast and snacks. The view from the lounge is also awesome! Rooms are small and yes, a little dated, but Iâ€™ve always found them clean and comfortable. I've never had an issue with noise either from the hallway or other rooms. Rates for hotel can be all over the place. Sometimes I look and they are well over $300, other times in the mid to high $100's. I feel extremely comfortable recommending at a rate of $199 or even as high as $249. Over that, I'd say you may want to look elsewhere. Finally, parking is expensive (I think $49) but you can park in the lot directly across the street (Sutter & Stockton garage) for much less.

I enjoyed the service and the people there were great! When I first arrived at the hotel there were people there to escort my belongings to the inside of the hotel and then I was able to be carefree about signing in. The service was fast and quick. I really did love the people there. The stay at Hyatt San Francisco was a trip to never forget! I will be sure to tell others about this hotela and how I had a great stay there! On top of that, I was able to meet the man of my dreams! Thank You

The Grand Hyatt is situated one block from Union Square and within walking distance to many of San Francisco's greatest attractions. Room was fine. I was surprised that there was no desk in the room. There was a small corner table where I had to work and plugging in the laptop was a bit difficult. Outlets were hard to find.Still, they had a great AAA rate and you can't beat the location. Perfect for leisure travel.Rooftop restaurant/lounge is worth checking out. Beautiful views of the city.
I stay in over 200 hotels a year and this is one of the stand-outs, great people, great service and great views all make for a wonderful experience

We stayed at the Hyatt for 5 days, I thought the location was perfect, it was right beside union square, which was nice when you got a little turned around while walking. All you had to find was union square and you seen your hotel. We got there very early (about 8:30am) They told us people from 2 rooms had checked out and gave us a choice between great view but 2 double beds or ok view with king, if we wanted to check in early. We decided on the great view. We were able to check in an hour later. The service from the front desk to the housekeeping was exceptional. The first day house keeping came to the room, very early, we told her we will be out of the room every day by 10am so after that she never came until after 10, but was always done by 12. The conciere was helpful with any thing we wanted. The front desk even gave us a late check out at no extra charge. We hope to come back next year and we will stay here again.

This was my first stay at the Grand Hyatt and overall I'd say that the service I received from the Front Desk staff and doormen were the things that truly made my stay go above and beyond just average. The decor in the lobby and rooms was nice, but nothing that was great or fabulosity personified. I found the Housekeeping staff to be a bit pushy about wanting to push me out of my room by calling me and knocking on my door repeatedly (and then giving me the evil eye while they stood around in a group right outside my door when I did finally leave my room after the first day), but the Room Service staff were highly proficient and thorough in completing tasks. When I arrived the lobby was filled with throngs of people milling about in different groups and employees going about their duties and I got discouraged thinking that it would take forever to be noticed, as I was traveling by myself, and get checked into my room. To my surprise, I was noticed by a wonderful woman named Isabella who beckoned me over and greeted me with a smile and kindness with no hint of stress or strain in her demeanor or voice and she deftly checked me in. When she told me that I was in a nonsmoking room and I asked if a smoking was available she told me that none were for that day, but that there was starting on the next day of my stay and she made all the arrangements to have my reservation moved to the new room on the next day and all I had to do was leave my packed bags in my room when I left for the day and the staff would move my belongings for me and she even upgraded me from the 4th floor to the 19th floor (truly as other reviews have stated, the views on the upper floors are to die for and would be worth paying extra for if necessary). Needless to say, I was grateful and extremely pleased with the service I received. When it came time for my original check out date, I decided that I was having too much fun in San Francisco (how can you not in that great city?!?) and that I wanted to stay for another day, so I went down to the Front Desk and inquired about doing so and the staff member who helped me was happy to accommodate my request and did so with a smile. On the day that I was leaving, I was running late and left in a harried rush and was obviously noticed by the Doorman who asked my destination and I informed him that I intended on taking a cab to the airport, and he told me that he could see I was rushing and offered a Lincoln Towncar from the hotel fleet for the same price as the cab. Of course I accepted the offer, if for no other reason than the extra comfort of the leather seats and better suspension on the vehicle, and then I heard the Doorman tell the driver that I seemed to be running late and to "step on it". I was impressed that I never once told him how really late that I was, yet he observed my demeanor and took the initiative of his own accord to let the driver know my situation to see if it would help get me to the airport on time....which it did. I barely made my flight, but I made it. Overall, the accommodations at this hotel were pleasant and somewhat appropriate for the price point, my interactions with the Housekeeping staff left something to be desired, but the negative of those brief interactions was far overshadowed by the excellent above par service that I received from the Front Desk staff and Door staff. I'd recommend this hotel if asked about it, but I don't think I would necessarily go out of my way to suggest it to someone if asked for names of hotels in the area to stay at.

From the moment we entered, the conceirge and staff behind the desk (Sebastian), were so helpful, attentitive and friendly. The location of this hotel is fantastic. Walk to everything.I would definitely recommend this hotel to anyone staying in San Francisco who wants to be close to city centre, shops and restaurants. If I had been travelling with my family (kids), I would probably consider staying at Fisherman's Wharf.

After my stay at the Hyatt in Monterey I arrived at the hotel with some intrepidation - this was quickly put to sleep on my arrival - great doorman and bell captain welcoming me to the hotel and escorting me to the front desk. The front desk experience was exceptional, a warm welcome and ask how my vacation was to date - apologies for my below average stay in Monterey and an upgrade to the Club Floor as way of an apology.The hotels location is fantastic just up from union square which makes the hotel very accessible to all the sights, BART, MUNI and cable cars. The hotel is on 36 floors and it is worth paying for an upgrade for a view of the bay - stunning vistas of the bay, Alcatraz and South San Francisco.Rooms are comfortable and clean, I had some of the best night sleeps of my trip here, but the rooms are on the old style and could do with some modernisation but not enough to ruin a stay in my opinion.The club floor is great as you get complimentary continental breakfast, evening snacks, and desserts as well as complimentary soft drinks and hot beverages - there's plentiful supplys of all and it gets refreshed continuously.The concierge team were fantastic and knew everything you could possibly want to do and ask for in San Francisco and can help you with the organisation of it all.First class service here - and you were made to feel like a VIP

I agree with past opinions as I reviewed as well before we booked this flight on FunJet. We got a great price with flight and hotel for $435.00 a person for nights/5 days from Milwaukee, WI. The best about the hotel is the location and the service. It is in a prime location and was super easy to get to from airport by taking the Bart train for only $8.00 a person and then walked up a few blocks. We arrived at noon and our check in was for 3:00 pm, the front desk was able to check us in early and checked us in to floor 21 rather than 3-12 level our FunJet reservations called for. So, we were delighted with that. First impressions of room was nice, a little outdated with decor and TV and it did smell a little musty, but we had the air conditioning on the whole time. The bed was "all that" with the comfort and the pillows. That was our favorite part of the room. For the price we paid for our vacation, the hotel was what we thought it would be.
